title-group.article-title: Synthesis and characterization of acid polyurethane–hydroxyapatite composites for biomedical applications

article-meta.aff: 1Romanian Academy – Institute of Macromolecular Chemistry ‘Petru Poni’, Romania
2Laboratory of Nanostructured Materials, National R&D Institute for Non-Ferrous and Rare Metals, Romania
3Laboratory of Plant Physiology and Morphology, Agricultural University of Athens, Greece

author-notes.corresp: LM Popescu, Romanian Academy – Institute of Macromolecular Chemistry ‘Petru Poni’, 41 A Grigore Ghica Voda Alley, Iasi 700487, Romania. Email: mpopescu@imnr.ro

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article aims to optimize the synthesis parameters and to establish the appropriate value of pressure for the design of polyurethane/hydroxyapatite organic matrix composites with an enhanced thermal and chemical stability. Strong interactions between Ca2+ ions and COO− groups are favoured at 60 atm. For the first time, the potential of polyurethane/hydroxyapatite material to be used as synthetic scaffold for bone cancer diagnosis was tested. The ability of polyurethane/hydroxyapatite coatings to be used as substrates for N2a cells attachment was studied using inverted optical microscopy. N2a cells presented a high birefringence and projected small prolongations of the soma comparable to control conditions, thus indicating the healthy state of the cells seeded on the composite substrates, especially in the case of composites prepared at 60–80 atm.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Biomedical engineering remains one of the most challenging application fields for nanostructured materials.1,2 Rapid advancements have been already made in a wide variety of biomedical applications using nanostructured materials, such as tissue engineered scaffolds, site-specific drug delivery systems, non-viral gene carriers and biosensors.2,3 As an example, polyurethane (PU)-based scaffolds have been reported to be useful in bone matrix stabilization and regeneration, as well as in several other medical devices, including heart valves and artificial skin.4–6 Despite its bio-absorbability and bio-stability, PUs have some drawbacks that limit their use in biomedical field: very slow biodegradation rates, no bioactive groups and toxic by-products generated through degradation.7,8

The successful use of PUs in medical applications was made possible by introduction of various functional groups into the polymeric chain, which led to the generation of various ceramic–polymer nanocomposites with several improved properties.9,10 These properties include strength via the ceramic phase, toughness and plasticity via the polymer phase, more favourable degradation and resorption kinetics and graded mechanical stiffness.11,12 Hydroxyapatite (HAP), one of the most popular bioceramic, was successfully used for the preparation of ceramic/polymer nanocomposites with applications in bone tissue engineering.13–16 However, a major difficulty related to the use of nanoHAP-polymer composites is the weak binding strength between the nanoHAP filler and the polymer matrix. This is because they do not covalently interact during the mixing process, being structurally different materials.4

Trying to overcome this problem, several publications have assumed that it might be possible to obtain stronger interactions between HAP nanoparticles (NPs) and the polymer using special functional groups of polymer able to interact with the hydroxyl groups of the HAP NPs.17

Based on these findings, we have systematically addressed the synthesis and characterization of a novel PU/HAP composite material using hydrothermal method as an innovative preparation route and a 100% hard segment PU functionalized with COOH groups on its surface which ensures a better interaction with HAP and an increased hydrophilicity. Resulting composite could be used as synthetic scaffold for imaging tools in the detection of cancer and/or drug delivery system in bone cancer.

In a previous paper,18 we have studied two types of composites: (a) with inorganic matrix (PU:HAP = 1:4 molar ratio) and (b) with organic matrix (PU:HAP = 4:1 molar ratio), establishing the role of pressure in the formation of strong interactions between the two components. The next step was to investigate the influence of pressure on PU treated in hydrothermal conditions, in the absence of HAP.19 We have concluded that significant effects on PU conformation and thermal properties appear in the pressure range of 60–80 atm. The potential of molecular dynamics method to simulate composite structures depending on synthesis conditions has been exploited in Popescu et al.20 Preliminary experiments of cellular viability were reported.20

This article aims to optimize the synthesis parameters and to establish the appropriate value of pressure for the design of PU/HAP organic matrix composites (PU:HAP = 4:1 weight ratio) with an enhanced thermal and chemical stability. The effect of pressure on composite’s structure, morphology and biocompatibility is discussed in detail. For the first time, the potential of PU/HAP material to be used as synthetic scaffold for bone cancer diagnosis was tested. Thus, the ability of PU/HAP coatings to be used as substrates for mouse neuroblastoma (N2a) cells proliferation was studied using inverted optical microscopy. N2a cells were selected because they are adherent to biomaterial surface21 and could help to identify bone lesions as neuroblastoma knowing that the surface charge applied to polarized HAP promotes specific orienting of neuroblastoma cells.22,23 The possibility to obtain PU/HAP thin films able to discriminate between normal and transformed (cancerous) cells and the design of an imaging tool based on PU/HAP composite as synthetic scaffold for bone cancer diagnosis will be addressed in near future.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Calcium nitrate (Ca(NO3)2 4H2O) and ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (NH4H2PO4) of analytical grade were purchased from Merck. Ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) 25% solution (pure chemical reagent) was purchased from Chimopar, Bucharest. Isophorone diisocyanate, tartaric acid and dibutyltin dilaurate of synthetic grade were purchased from Aldrich.

sec.title: Synthesis of PU functionalized with carboxylic groups
sec.p:
Acid PU with a proportion of 100% of hard segments was synthesized by a polyaddition performed in dry dimethylacetamide starting from 5 g isophorone diisocyanate (22.52 mmol) and a corresponding stoechiometric amount of tartaric acid (3.378 g). Dibutiltin dilaurate was used as the catalyst and the reaction was carried out under purified nitrogen at 65°C for 10 h. The evolution of the reaction was monitored with Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy until the isocyanate and hydroxyl groups were reacted, as confirmed by the disappearance of their stretching bands located at 2260 and 3480 cm−1, respectively. The resulting acid polymer was precipitated in methanol and dried for 48 h at 60°C under reduced pressure. The structure of hard PU is given in Figure 1, as previously reported.19,24 Figure 1.
Structure of PU functionalized with COOH groups. PU: polyurethane.

sec.title: Hydrothermal synthesis of PU/HAP composites
sec.p: Organic–inorganic nanostructured composites were prepared by hydrothermal process. First, Ca(NO3)2 4H2O was dissolved in distilled water and NH4H2PO4 was added drop-wise into the Ca(NO3)2 solution, under mechanical stirring to obtain a slurry, and the pH of the slurry was adjusted to 10 with ammonia solution (25%). The synthesized PU was dissolved in 5% (w/v) N,N-dimethylacetamide solvent. After complete mixing, polymer solution was added to the inorganic slurry and then stirred at room temperature for 20–30 min to obtain a homogeneous mixture. Theoretical weight ratio of the PU/HAP nanocomposites was 4:1. The organic–inorganic slurry was transferred into stainless steel autoclave for 3 h of hydrothermal treatment at high pressure (40–80 atm) and low temperature (<120°C), and then cooled to room temperature naturally. After hydrothermal process, nanostructured composites were washed with distilled water until the pH value approached 7. The resultant powder was dried at 60°C for 8 h.

Figure 2 shows a possible structure of PU/HAP composite, drawn based on molecular dynamics predictions discussed in Popescu et al.20 Figure 2.
Possible structure of PU/HAP nanostructured composites. PU: polyurethane; HAP: hydroxyapatite.

sec.title: Preparation of PU/HAP thin films for biocompatibility test
sec.p: Nanostructured composite powders obtained as described above were re-dispersed in water and prepared as stable suspensions for spin coating deposition, using poly(acrylic acid sodium salt) as dispersant. The appropiate ratio between nanocomposite and dispersing agent has been selected enabling the formation of a stable colloidal suspension.

The substrate used in this case was Si/SiO2/Ti/Au. Thin films based on PU/HAP composites could be further used for cancer detection, as mentioned above. The presence of a conductive thin layer of gold on the substrate will ensure the measurement of changes of the cell membrane potential by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Different physicochemical characteristics (morphology, shapes, agglomeration and spectral signature) of the particles are linked to their toxicity. Therefore, it is necessary to thoroughly characterize the particles prior to toxicity assessment.

The calcium and phosphorus contents in PU/HAP composites treated at various pressures were determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS ZEEnit 700, Analytic Jena AG, Germany) and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometry (Spectroflame P – Germany), respectively. Molecular structures of the samples synthesized at different pressures were characterized using FT-IR spectroscopy. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the transmission mode on a ABB MB 3000 spectrometer between 4000 and 550 cm−1 wavenumbers, and consisted of 64 scans at 4 cm−1 resolution. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of nanostructured powders were obtained using Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with monochromatic Cu-Kα radiation. Scans were obtained in the 2θ range = 4 ÷ 74°, with a step size of 0.02° every 2 s. Morphological observations were carried out by electron microscopy using a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin Field Emission high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM), with a 50–300 kV electron source and magnifications of 58 × −970 k × (transmission electron microscope) and 150 × −230 M × (scanning transmission electron microscope). Particle size measurements have been performed through DigitalMicrograph™, Gatan Inc. image acquisition and processing software. Thermal stability of the composites was studied using thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. TG measurements were carried out at a ramp rate of 10°C/min−1, from 0°C to 700°C in a nitrogen flow with a TA Instruments TGA Q5000 V3.13 Build 261. Platinum pans were used.

sec.title: Cell culture using N2a cells
sec.p: Mouse neuroblastoma cells (N2a) were cultured at 37°C in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium and supplemented with 10% foetal bovine serum, 2% antibiotics (200 mg/mL penicillium and 200 mg/mL streptomycin), NaHCO3, L-alanyl-L-glutamine and sodium pyruvate. Thin film composite samples deposited on Si/SiO2/Ti/Au substrates were placed into 24-well plates and sterilized by UV radiation for 24 h.

sec.title: Proliferation of N2a cells on PU/HAP thin films
sec.p: The cells were seeded on composite samples at a density of 105 cells/well and the plate was kept at 37°C in a humidified CO2 atmosphere. After 24 h of culture, the proliferation of N2a cells was determined using the MTT (3 -(4,5-Dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay20,25 and inverted optical microscopy (Carl Zeiss microscope).

sec.title: Chemical analysis
sec.p:
The results obtained by chemical analysis for some representative PU/HAP composite powder treated at different pressures are presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Ca:P atomic ratio and percentage composition of nanostructured powders
Synthesis pressure (atm) Sample name Ca (%) P (%) Ca:P HAP (%) PU (%)
40 PU/HAP 40 6.67 2.67 1.94 15.3 84.7
60 PU/HAP 60 6.53 2.93 1.66 16.1 83.9
80 PU/HAP 80 7.58 3.51 1.67 19 81
HAP: hydroxyapatite; PU: polyurethane.

Ca:P atomic ratio for pure HAP with chemical formula Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2 is 1.66. The values obtained for PU/HAP composites suggest that the formation of HAP NPs is favoured by pressures above 40 atm. Based on Ca and P content given by AAS and ICP, respectively, chemical composition of the organic–inorganic material was calculated. PU matrix represents about 81–85% (wt.%) and the amount of HAP increases slowly with pressure. These results are confirmed by XRD where HAP has been identifed as the major crystalline phase in the case of PU/HAP 60 and PU/HAP 80 samples, in good agreement with that of the standard HAP crystallites (Ca5(PO4)3OH, PDF reference 09-0432), as depicted in Figure 3. Samples prepared at 40 atm, with higher Ca:P atomic ratio showed another crystalline phase, namely brushite CaHPO4 2H2O (PDF reference 01-072-0713). It means that the formation of nanocrystalline HAP is not favoured by this pressure or HAP crystallites are too small to be detected by XRD. Optimum conditions for the synthesis of PU/HAP composites are around 60 atm. Figure 3.
XRD spectra of PU/HAP composites. XRD: X-ray diffraction; PU: polyurethane; HAP: hydroxyapatite.

sec.title: FT-IR spectroscopy of PU/HAP composites
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the comparative FT-IR spectra of PU/HAP composites prepared at different pressures and acid PU before mixing with inorganic phase. Figure 4.
FT-IR spectra of various PU/HAP composites compared to spectrum of pure PU. FT-IR: Fourier-transform infrared; PU: polyurethane; HAP: hydroxyapatite.

The absorption bands confirm the chemical structural characteristics of carboxylic PU. Band at 3326 cm−1 is assigned to N–H stretching mode of PU. In polymer composites, this band is shifted to 3314 cm−1 as a possible effect of pressure on PU structure. The bands at 2954, 2906 and 2846 cm−1 corresponded to symmetric or asymmetric stretching vibrations of CH2 and could be found in all samples presented in Figure 4. Other PU peaks were observed at 1462, 1386, 1366, 1310 and 1246 cm−1 and belong to bending vibration of CH3 or CH2 groups.

The peak at 1746 cm−1 is the free C = O group in polymer, but it is not observed in composites spectra, showing that a chemical bond was formed between carboxyl groups (PU) and Ca2+ (from HAP structure).

Characteristic PU bands at 1634 and 1558 cm−1, assigned to amides I and II, respectively, were identified in samples prepared at 40 and 60 atm. Amide I band was shifted to 1646 cm−1 in the case of PU/HAP80 composite. Also, it can be observed that in the case of samples synthesized at 80 atm, characteristic vibrational mode of the phosphate group at 1034 cm−1 corresponding to ν3 (PO4)3− is shifted to 1070 cm−1. The other characteristic peak at 1118 cm−1 corresponding to ν3 (PO4)3− appears as a small shoulder with low intensity. This could be due to the sterical hindrance of the phosphate group. Bands at 962, 866, 602 and 562 cm−1 are assigned to vibration of the phosphate group, (PO4) in HAP and are found in samples prepared at 40 and 60 atm.

sec.title: Morphology of PU/HAP composites
sec.p:
Some representative HRTEM images of PU/HAP composites synthesized at different pressures are presented in Figure 5. Morphology of simple HAP prepared in hydrothermal conditions at 60 atm is presented, for comparison in Figure 5(d). Figure 5.
HRTEM images of some representative PU/HAP composites synthesized at: (a) 40 atm (thin whiskers of HAP could be seen inside circles); (b) 60 atm; and (c) 80 atm (needle-like HAP are highlighted); (d) HRTEM image of HAP synthesized in hydrothermal conditions at 60 atm; and (e) HRTEM micrograph of PU before hydrothermal reaction with HAP precursors. HRTEM: high resolution transmission electron microscope; PU: polyurethane; HAP: hydroxyapatite.

By increasing pressure, morphology of HAP in PU/HAP composites changes from thin whiskers to needle like particles. PU particles which represent the composite matrix could not be highlighted because the hard PU used is completely amorphous, as it may be observed in Figure 5(e). Length of HAP crystallite increases with pressure (Figure 5). HAP whiskers with a maximum length of 20 nm and about 2 nm in thickness could barely be seen inside composite structures prepared at 40 atm. Higher pressure leads to needle like HAP crystallites of 50 nm (for samples prepared at 60 atm) or 100 nm (for samples prepared at 80 atm), embedded in polymer matrix.

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p:
TG analysis of nanostructured composites was performed to investigate their thermal stability at different pressures. TG thermographs of three representative samples are shown in Figure 6, comparing to TG curve of hard PU. The weight loss percentage of each sample is listed in Table 2. Figure 6.
TGA thermographs of three representative samples (a) compared to single PU (b). TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; PU: polyurethane.
Table 2.
Thermal properties of PU/HAP composites compared to pure PU
Sample name Temperature range (°C) Mass loss (%) Assignment Residue at 700°C
PU/HAP 40 0–200 10.10 Water loss 19.67%
200–400 55.86 Polymer decomposition
400–600 12.32
PU/HAP 60 0–200 9.39 Water loss 20.30%
200–400 57.77 Polymer decomposition
400–600 11.89
PU/HAP 80 0–200 10.45 Water loss 21.95%
200–400 52.02 Polymer decomposition
400–600 13.19
PU (raw material) 0–100 4.34 Water loss 7.87%
100–300 29.36 Polymer decomposition
300–600 57.97
PU: polyurethane; HAP: hydroxyapatite.

Decomposition of the organic–inorganic materials is observed around 315–320°C, irrespective of the applied pressure. In a previous paper,19 it has been shown that hydrothermally treated PUs decompose in two steps, starting at 250°C and lying on a wide range of temperature, respectively, until 360°C. Based on these findings, the decomposition of PU/HAP nanostructures in one step, at a higher temperature than that where polymer decomposition or melting starts could be due to PU–HAP interactions and formation of composites. The residual weight at 700°C (around 20% of the original mass) could be attributed to HAP and corresponds with theoretical gravimetric composition of the composite (PU:HAP = 4:1). PU/HAP nanostructured materials are more stable than acid PU due to the formation of chemical bonds between organic and inorganic components. Composite materials prepared at 60 atm are the most thermally stable and no thermal effects are observed until 321°C, with the exception of water evaporation.

sec.title: Proliferation of N2a cells on PU/HAP thin films
sec.p:
In terms of cellular viability, PU/HAP composites synthesized at 60 atm represent the best substrate for N2a proliferation, followed by samples prepared at 80 and 40 atm, respectively, as it was shown in Popescu et al.20 These results could be correlated with samples morphology presented above. It is known that surface area to volume ratio increases with the decrease of particle size, meaning that the number of surface molecules increases exponentially with the decrease of particle size. This leads to a massive increase in chemical and biological activity potential, but it is a two-sided issue. On the one hand, increased biological activity can be very beneficial for ‘antioxidant activity, carrier capacity for therapeutics, and penetration of cellular barriers’.26 However, toxicity and oxidative stress of cellular functions may also dramatically increase.27 In our case, the smallest crystallite size has been observed for PU/HAP composites prepared at 40 atm. Bigger particles of HAP (around 100 nm) appeared in samples synthesized at 80 atm. Morphology of N2a cells growing on three representative composite coatings after 24 h of culture is presented in Figure 7, compared to, uncoated Si/SiO2/Ti/Au substrate used as control. Figure 7.
Morphology of murine neuroblastoma cell growing for 24 h on: (a) control (uncoated Si/SiO2/Ti/Au); (b) PU/HAP40 coated on Si/SiO2/Ti/Au; (c) PU/HAP 60 coated on Si/SiO2/Ti/Au; and (d) PU/HAP 80 coated on Si/SiO2/Ti/Au. PU: polyurethane; HAP: hydroxyapatite.

Figure 7 highlights the ability of PU/HAP coatings to be used as substrates for N2a cells attachment, which confirms previous studies of cellular viability.20 In accordance with MTT test presented in Popescu et al.,20 neither morphological differences nor apparent changes in cell density were observed between the different conditions. Cells presented a high birefringence and projected small prolongations of the soma comparable to control conditions, thus indicating the healthy state of the cells seeded on the composite substrates, especially in the case of composites prepared at 60–80 atm. As a remark, one could say that PU/HAP composites obtained at 60 atm, with HAP crystallites of 50 nm in length and homogenously distributed inside PU matrix could be used as synthetic scaffolds for the design of an imaging tool with potential applications in bone cancer diagnosis. The use of PU with 100% hard segments ensures an increased solubility in aqueous solution and a better interaction with HAP, leading to scaffolds with controlled porosity. These scaffolds will be studied in future works as possible delivery systems for anti-cancer drugs, assuming that they are stable enough in the biological medium without decomposing or releasing toxic secondary products in the surrounding tissue.

sec.title: The influence of pressure on composite structure
sec.p: According to Rivalain et al.,28 the pressure dependence P of the Gibbs energy is given by the following equation: (δ(ΔG)/δP)T=-ΔV/RT<label>(1)</label> in which ΔV is the reaction volume change of the system, including intrinsic (van der Waals volumes) and solvational (contraction of the solvation shell and change in volume of the cavities). Consequently, the main effect of pressure is to displace the equilibrium towards the state characterized by the smallest volume.

Under high pressure conditions (P = 80 atm), the dissociation of water is increased and the value of the equilibrium constant is improved. But high pressure can cause the rearrangement of Ca2+ or PO43− ions in a more compact structure which hinders some vibration modes of the phosphate group, as it can be seen in Figure 5. If the pressure is too high (80 atm), polymer would shrink, which is not favourable for interactions with HAP. Instead, a pressure of 60 atm favours stronger interactions between Ca2+ ions and COO− groups and lead to a composite material which represents a better substrate for N2a cells proliferation. In this case, the main factor characterizing the hydrothermal reaction system is the compressibility (negative value of ΔV) of the solution which leads to the reduction of the average distance between the solvated species. All these phenomena lead to an improvement of chemical reactivity and to the stabilization of PU/HAP composite structure.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Nanostructured composites based on acid PU matrix and HAP NPs have been prepared by hydrothermal synthesis at high pressure (40–80 atm) and low temperature (<120°C). It has been observed that pressures of 60 atm favour stronger interactions between Ca2+ ions from HAP and functional COO− groups of the polymer and leads to composites with an enhanced thermal and chemical stability, which determined us to assume that they are stable enough in the biological medium without decomposing or releasing toxic secondary products in the surrounding tissue.

Under higher pressure conditions (P = 80 atm), Ca2+ or PO43− ions might be rearranged in a more compact structure which hinders some vibration modes of the phosphate group. Also, PU shrinkage occurs and coordinative interactions between organic (PU) and inorganic (HAP) components are not favoured in this case. Pressure is the main factor which determines the interaction between organic and inorganic components in hydrothermal conditions, by decreasing distances between functional groups of PU and inorganic species.

For the first time, the potential of PU/HAP material to be used as synthetic scaffold for bone cancer diagnosis was tested. N2a cells presented a high birefringence and projected small prolongations of the soma comparable to control conditions, thus indicating the healthy state of the cells seeded on the composite substrates, especially in the case of composites prepared at 60–80 atm. Viability of N2a cells depends on composite morphology (nearly like a porous network at 60 atm, Figure 5(b)) which is dictated by pressure. These results are also promising for future preparation of an anti-cancer drug delivery system based on PU/HAP composite scaffolds with controlled porosity and good dispersability in aqueous media. Further in vitro test will be done in the near future to establish a possible mechanism for cellular adhesion at bio/non-bio interface.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: LM Popescu and T Buruiana wish to thank the European Social Fund, ‘Cristofor I. Simionescu’ postdoctoral fellowship Program, contract no. POSDRU/89/1.5/S/55216. CF Rusti and RM Piticescu would like to acknowledge PNII Programme, contract no. 71-004/2007.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
